newsitem.title: BELGIUM: French election reignites political doubts on EMU.
newsitem.headline: French election reignites political doubts on EMU.

text.p: French parliamentary elections, likely to be called on Monday, will either put Europe's planned common currency firmly on track or provoke more doubts about the project, analysts say.
French President Jacques Chirac is widely expected to call early elections on Monday evening for late May or early June instead of March 1998 as originally scheduled.

If the centre-right coalition clearly holds on to power, it would win an almost free hand for tough budget policies before economic and monetary union's (EMU) planned launch in 1999 and much-needed economic reforms thereafter.

But a strong performance by the Socialists, committed to EMU but opposed to big budget cuts, could cast doubt on the project as a launch would be unthinkable without France -- the main power behind EMU along with Germany.
"If the current majority wins the election the probability for monetary union to start on time is even higher," said Patrick Mange, economist at Deutsche Morgan Grenfell in Paris.
German Chancellor Helmut Kohl's recent decision to stand for re-election in 1998 has bolstered expectations that the single currency, the euro, will begin on schedule.
Recent technical decisions by European Union finance ministers on the blueprint for the euro have also restored confidence in the process.
But with Chirac likely to announce early polls in an address to the French nation, political uncertainty has once again been injected into the EMU process.

Analysts and officials are particularly worried that the Socialists and far right might win a large percentage of parliamentary seats. This would weaken the government's position and fuel doubts on financial markets over austerity measures.

"If there is cohabitation then that's obviously not very good," said a senior EU official. Cohabitation is the French term for having the president in one party and the lower house of parliament dominated by another.

Many experts believe France will have to raise social security charges in the next few months to cut its 1997 budget deficit close to three percent of gross domestic product -- the Maastricht treaty's target for EMU. The finance ministry denies this.

Under a strong right-wing coalition, higher charges should pose no problem. But the task is likely to be much harder if the right has to negotiate with a hostile opposition aware of weakening public support for EMU.
"In a situation where the governing coalition loses the election, it's extremely difficult to assess the consequences," said Olivier Davanne, co-director for research at Goldman Sachs in Paris.

Socialist leader Lionel Jospin sternly opposes any additional budget cuts at a time of high unemployment. In a television interview on Sunday he noted that Germany itself was struggling to meet the EMU budget target.

"If to respect the criteria of three percent -- which Germany will probably not respect -- if to do that we have to impose, with the jobless rate we have...a new cure of austerity on the country my answer is no," he said.

But as the Socialists also believe monetary union is in the best interests of France and Europe, some economists believe they could take a more flexible stand on budget cuts to meet EMU criteria in future.
